{{POV|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox person |name = Tzvetan Vassilev |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1959|08|12|}} |birth_place = [[Gabrovo]], [[People's Republic of Bulgaria]] |nationality = [[Bulgarian nationality law|Bulgarian]] |alma_mater = [[University of National and World Economy]] |occupation = Chairman of the Supervisory Board of Corporate Commercial Bank AD |years_active = 1985–present }}
'''Tsvetan Vasilev''' (also spelled Tzvetan Vassilev; {{lang-bg|Цветан Василев}}; born 1959) is a former [[Bulgarian people|Bulgarian]] entrepreneur nowadays fugitive from the Bulgarian court. He was indicted for the embezzlement of billions of Corpbank with 17 other accomplices but is now sued in absentia. The reason is that he refuses to stand before the Bulgarian court and hides in Belgrade [https://www.reuters.com/article/us-bulgaria-corpbank-trial/bulgaria-files-indictment-in-1-5-billion-corpbank-embezzlement-probe-idUSKBN1A51HM Reuters reports]. Besides being sued in Bulgaria for the Corpbank affair also known as the "Robbery of the century", he is being investigated in Serbia for deliberate bankruptcy of a glass factory in Parachin, financed by Corpbank while the bank was still under the control of Vassilev [https://www.blic.rs/vesti/drustvo/bugarski-tajkun-trazi-zastitu-u-srbiji-ortak-tome-nikolica-pokusava-da-se-spase/v92lhjq here]. According to the Serbian publication "Blic" Vasilev is being investigated also by the Austrian authorities.
== Allegations and Trial ==
The indictment for the syphoning off of Corporate Commercial Bank was filed by the Specialized Prosecutor’s Office on 20 July 2017, Bulgarian National TV reported [https://www.bnt.bg/en/a/18-people-indicted-for-the-corpbank-siphoning-off here]. All copies of the indictment include more than 210,000 pages. 18 persons have been indicted, including Tzvetan Vasssilev who is being sued as the mastermind of the organised crime group whose activity syphoned off the bank. The charges pressed against the convicts exceed 5,000 pages. More than 400 witnesses have been interviewed. Over 90 expert’s reports have been prepared by 27 experts. The collected evidence is in 1,360 volumes. Among the indicted is the former deputy governor of Bulgaria’s central bank (BNB), Tzvetan Gounev, along with the former CEOs of the bank.
== Years of Bloom ==
Vasilev is former chairman of the supervisory board of [[Corporate Commercial Bank]] AD, the fifth bank in Bulgaria based on assets, which collapsed after a bank run in 2014.<ref>[http://www.bnb.bg/BankSupervision/BSCreditInstitution/BSCIFinansReports/BSCIFRBankingSystem/BS_201307_BG Official website of the Bulgarian National Bank (the central bank of Bulgaria)] {{bg icon}}</ref> as well as its majority shareholder.<ref>[http://corpbank.bg/managment_Tzvetan-Vassilev_3.html Official website of Corporate Commercial Bank AD] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927075300/http://corpbank.bg/managment_Tzvetan-Vassilev_3.html |date=2013-09-27 }}</ref> Tsvetan Vasilev is also former chairman of the supervisory board of Victoria FATA Insurance<ref>[http://victoria-insbg.com/en/?load=AboutUs Official website of Victoria FATA Insurance] {{en icon}}</ref> as well as the supervisory board of Vivacom, a Bulgarian telecom company.<ref>[http://www.vivacom.bg/en/residential/about_us/supervisory_board Official website of Vivacom] {{en icon}}</ref> Vasilev is the recipient of the badge of honor of the [[University of National and World Economy]] in Sofia<ref>[http://www.unwe.bg/en/pages/305/honorary-titles-.html Honorary Titles, Official website of the University of National and World Economy] {{en icon}}</ref> and ''[[Doctor Honoris Causa]]'' of the "St Ivan Rilski" University of Mining and Geology.<ref>[http://www.monitor.bg/article?id=164906 Corporate Commercial Bank AD Gives Two Annual Awards to Top Geology Students, ''Monitor'' newspaper, 31 July 2008. Retrieved 8 September 2013.] {{bg icon}}</ref>
In July 2017, Bulgaria's prosecution indicted Vasilev with embezzlement.<ref>[https://www.prb.bg/bg/news/aktualno/specializiranata-prokuratura-predade-na-sd-18-lica/ Official website of the Prosecutor's Office of Republic of Bulgaria] {{bg icon}}</ref> Since September 2014, Vasilev has been living in exile in Serbia where he faces extradition proceedings <ref>[http://www.mediapool.bg/srabskite-magistrati-otkazaha-da-ekstradirat-tsvetan-vasilev-news231534.html Сръбските магистрати отказаха да екстрадират Цветан Василев, казусът се връща на първа инстанция, съобщиха от Апелативния съд в Белград, ''Mediapool'' newspaper, 11 March 2015. Retrieved 28 March 2018.] {{bg icon}}</ref> and investigation for deliberate bankruptcy <ref>[https://www.blic.rs/vesti/drustvo/krimi-porodica-bugarskog-tajkuna-cerka-radosveta-hapsena-u-srbiji-interpol-trazi-i/l7d6hns] {{bg icon}}</ref>
== Education == Tsvetan Vasilev holds a master's degree in International Economic Relations from the University of National and World Economy. After graduation, he worked as a research fellow in economics at the Center of Foreign Trade and International Markets for seven years.<ref>[http://spisanie.manager.bg/broi-120/menidzhmant/nay-skapite-klienti The Dearest Clients, ''The Manager'' magazine, October 2008. Retrieved 27 August 2013.] {{bg icon}}</ref>
== Early career ==
Tsvetan Vasilev started his career in finance in 1992 when he founded his brokerage company Bromak EOOD<ref>[http://www.bromak.eu/ Bromak EOOD official website] {{en icon}}</ref> and his investment intermediary Fina-S AD.<ref>[http://www.fina-s.com/инвестиционен-посредник_0&lang=en Fina-S AD official website] {{en icon}}</ref> Between 1995 and 1999 he headed the Foreign Exchange Operations and Liquidity Department of Central Cooperative Bank, and in 1997 he also became member of the bank's board of directors. In 1999 he left Central Cooperative Bank to head the Markets and Liquidity Department at CB Bulgaria Invest (now Allianz Bulgaria Commercial Bank).
== Corporate Commercial Bank ("Corpbank") == Between 2000 and 2003, Vasilev served as chairman of the executive board and executive director of Corporate Commercial Bank AD. In 2003 he became its majority shareholder and chairman of its supervisory board.<ref>[http://corpbank.bg/managment_Tzvetan-Vassilev_3.html Corporate Commercial Bank AD official website] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927075300/http://corpbank.bg/managment_Tzvetan-Vassilev_3.html |date=2013-09-27 }}</ref>
=== Entrepreneurial and innovative investments === By 2014, Corpbank was Bulgaria’s fourth-largest bank.<ref name=":13">{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/bulgaria-lawsuit-idUSL5N16P5MS|title=UPDATE 1-Bulgaria files $1.3 bln lawsuit against Corpbank's main shareholder|date=2017-03-17|newspaper=Reuters|access-date=2016-12-16}}</ref> The bank held an extensive portfolio of companies and was the only bank in Bulgaria investing in start-ups and entrepreneurs. Because the bank was making these types of investments that no other banks were doing, its profits and regional power grew. Until its destruction by Bulgarian regulators and the looting of its assets, Corpbank was arguably the most innovative and entrepreneurial bank in the Balkans.
Starting from scratch in 2001, it was a pioneer in [[Trade finance|export financing]] to Bulgarian [[Energy industry|energy]] producers and [[ammunition]] manufacturers previously without banking options. Unlike its rivals, Corpbank also made direct investments in its clients and emerging enterprises in Bulgaria, most notably the country's leading telecom [[Vivacom]], which it bought from [[creditor]]s along with affiliates of [[VTB Capital]] in 2012.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2012-08-13|title=VTB Capital, Corpbank Seek 73% in Bulgarian Telco Vivacom|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-299551788.html}}</ref><ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-11-12/vtb-corporate-bank-affiliates-buy-94-stake-in-vivacom-1-.html VTB, Corporate Bank Affiliates Buy 94% Stake in Vivacom, bloomberg.com, November 2012] {{en icon}}</ref> Vivacom is the leading market provider in Bulgaria for a variety of telecommunications services, including [[landline]], [[Mobile phone|mobile]], Internet, radio, and TV. It has approximately 3,500 employees.<ref name=":02"/> Vassilev saw the opportunity and raised the capital to make the purchase.<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url=http://readrussia.com/2016/02/11/vtb-capital-faces-fraud-accusations-in-the-uk-over-handling-of-a-loan/|title=VTB Capital Faces Fraud Accusations in the UK Over Handling of a Loan {{!}} Russia! Magazine|access-date=2016-12-16}}</ref>
Experts claim that the Vivacom deal was amidst the most complicated ones on the Bulgarian financial market.<ref>[http://boyanov.com/en/news/3964/ BOYANOV&Co. Advises on “Probably the Most Complicated Deal in Bulgaria Ever”, 6 September 2012, boyanov.com] {{en icon}}</ref> The restructuring was approved by the [[European Commission]] and the international creditors of [[Vivacom]].<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-11-12/vtb-corporate-bank-affiliates-buy-94-stake-in-vivacom-1-.html VTB, Corporate Bank Affiliates Buy 94% Stake in Vivacom, bloomberg.com, 12 November 12 2012] {{en icon}}</ref><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/06/vivacom-restructuring-idUSL6E8K6D6R20120906 Bulgaria's Vivacom gets court approval for restructuring, reuters.com, 6 September 2012] {{en icon}}</ref> Prior to the acquisition by Vasilev and VTB Capital, Vivacom had incurred significant debt after a buyout by AIG in 2007, which subsequently sold its shares to PineBridge Investments.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/01/28/bulgaria-vivacom-idUSL5N0AX6L220130128 Majority Owners of Bulgaria Telco Vivacom Make Buyout Offer, reuters.com, 28 January 2013. Retrieved 23 September 2013.]{{en icon}}</ref>
The company's 2013 financial report showed considerable improvement: EBITDA increased from BGN 267 million to BGN 339 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://s2.vivacom.bg/files/financial_reports/33/document/(31.12.13)%20VIVACOM%202013%20results%20presentation%20(published%20on%20March%2004,%202014).pdf|title=2013 Financial Report|last=|first=|date=|website=s2.vivacom.bg|publisher=Vivacom|access-date=}}</ref>
=== "Sudden" run on the bank === Because of its growth, wealth, and power, in April 2014 one of the most influential political parties in Bulgaria ([[Movement for Rights and Freedoms|DPS]]) visited Vassilev. The request was simple: transfer assets for free to the "[[Bulgarian mafia|mobster circle]] of DPS." Vassilev refused.
Suddenly, by June and July 2014, Corpbank customers withdrew cash in a panic. Prior to the bank run, several Bulgarian media outlets ran stories accusing Vassilev of trying to organize the murder of a media titan who had close connections to the government, [[Delyan Peevski]]. Prosecutors raided companies affiliated with Corpbank. They confiscated financial documents from those companies. TV stations ran live feeds of the prosecution's raids. Over the course of 4 days, over 20 percent of Corpbank's assets were withdrawn in cash by depositors.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/francescoppola/2015/10/05/bulgarias-failed-corpbank-the-former-owners-story/#5ba58e37e794|title=Bulgaria's Failed Corpbank: The Former Owner's Story|last=Coppola|first=Frances|newspaper=Forbes|access-date=2016-12-26}}</ref>
After the bank run, Corpbank was closed for six months. Customers could not get money out. The Bulgarian government's currency board denied the Bulgarian National Bank (BNB) from creating money to pay Corpbank's customers. According to Forbes, "Paying off depositors was therefore impossible. But reopening the bank was not an option either since that would simply re-start the run. Therefore, the BNB kept the bank "on ice".<ref name=":1" />
=== Bank collapse and shutdown === In late 2014, the bank collapsed which caused the largest [[financial crisis]] in Bulgaria since the 1990s. Bulgaria’s central bank, [[Bulgarian National Bank]], then took control over the bank. Corpbank was officially shut down and its assets taken over by the Bulgarian National Bank in July 2014. According to media reports at that time, the shutdown was due to a dispute between Vassilev and "Bulgarian media oligarch Delyan Peevski."<ref name=":1" />
=== Civil and criminal charges === In March 2016, the Bulgarian government (through the Commission for Illegal Assets Forfeiture (CIAF)) filed a lawsuit against Vassilev as the main shareholder of Corpbank. The lawsuit accuses Vassilev of using bank money to personally acquire assets and property. The government’s lawsuit seeks 2.2 billion [[Bulgarian lev|leva]], which is equivalent to $1.3 billion US dollars.<ref name=":13"/> Vassilev blames the failure of the bank on a plot hatched by his competitors and the government, ultimately to gain control over the wealthy telecommunications company [[Bulgarian Telecommunications Company|Vivacom]].<ref name=":13" /> In December 2016, Bulgarian and [[Switzerland|Swiss]] courts froze over 600 million levs of Vassilev’s money.<ref name=":13" />
The government is also going after Vassilev and his wife, charging both with money laundering. His wife is a university professor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://europost.bg/article?id=11769|title=Vassilev and spouse investigated for money laundering|website=europost.bg|access-date=2016-12-27}}</ref>
After spending some time in [[Austria]], Vasilev is currently residing in [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]] (he voluntarily surrendered to Serbian police officers on 16 September 2014). In March 2015, the Appellate Court of Belgrade ruled against an extradition request by the Bulgarian authorities.<ref>[http://www.mediapool.bg/srabskite-magistrati-otkazaha-da-ekstradirat-tsvetan-vasilev-news231534.html Сръбските магистрати отказаха да екстрадират Цветан Василев, казусът се връща на първа инстанция, съобщиха от Апелативния съд в Белград, ''Mediapool'' newspaper, 11 March 2015. Retrieved 16 March 2015.] {{bg icon}}</ref>
"Delyan Peevski is simply one of the main tools that the Bulgarian political mafia uses to blackmail Bulgarian business—the visible part of a rather large iceberg of corruption," Vassilev said in a ''Forbes'' interview. "The political mafia is persistently trying to downgrade what happened to Corpbank to a personal conflict between Mr. Peevski and me, which is utterly untrue. I had a conflict with the political mafia ruling the country, which has been blackmailing and threatening me for many years."<ref name=":23">{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/francescoppola/2015/10/05/bulgarias-failed-corpbank-the-former-owners-story/#5ba58e37e794|title=Bulgaria's Failed Corpbank: The Former Owner's Story|last=Coppola|first=Frances|newspaper=Forbes|access-date=2016-12-16}}</ref>
After inexplicably modifying charges several times, in July 2017 Bulgaria's prosecution indicted Vasilev with embezzlement along with 17 other people.<ref>[https://www.prb.bg/bg/news/aktualno/specializiranata-prokuratura-predade-na-sd-18-lica/ Official website of the Prosecutor's Office of Republic of Bulgaria)] {{bg icon}}</ref> According to Reuters, the case is "seen as one of the Balkan nation’s biggest post-communist fraud investigations". <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-bulgaria-corpbank-trial/bulgaria-files-indictment-in-1-5-billion-corpbank-embezzlement-probe-idUSKBN1A51HM|title=Bulgaria files indictment in $1.5 billion Corpbank embezzlement probe|website=reuters.com|access-date=2018-03-28}}</ref> Vasilev, however, argues that the charges are political.<ref>{{Cite web|url=htps://sofiaglobe.com/2018/03/27/bulgarian-court-denies-defence-motion-to-dismiss-ccb-embezzlement-lawsuit/|title= Bulgarian court denies defence motion to dismiss CCB embezzlement lawsuit|website=sofiaglobe.com|access-date=2018-03-28}}</ref> He has submitted applications against Bulgaria before the [[European Court of Human Rights]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/francescoppola/2015/10/05/bulgarias-failed-corpbank-the-former-owners-story/#5ba58e37e794|title=Bulgaria's Failed Corpbank: The Former Owner's Story|last=Coppola|first=Frances|newspaper=Forbes|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref> In August 2017, he also submitted an application under the US [[Magnitsky Act]], which sanctions corrupt government officials implicated in human rights abuses, against Bulgaria's General Prosecutor [[Sotir Tsatsarov]] and media mogul and Member of Parliament [[Delyan Peevski]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thehill.com/opinion/international/350503-in-bulgaria-global-magnitsky-act-sanctions-could-make-a-real-difference|title=In Bulgaria, Global Magnitsky Act could make a real difference|website=thehill.com|access-date=2018-03-28}}</ref>
===Corpbank's assets after the forced shutdown===
After Corpbank's shutdown, insolvency proceedings were officially initiated. Corpbank's clients, however, repeatedly warned that Bulgaria's authorities were violating the creditors' interests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://glasove.com/categories/skandalyt/news/osnovnite-modeli-za-ograbvane-na-masata-na-nesystoyatelnostta-v-ktb/|title=Основните модели за ограбване на масата на несъстоятелността в КТБ|publisher=glasove.com|language=Bulgarian|date= 29 November 2017|access-date=1 December 2017}}</ref> Media reported that assets were deviated by companies and persons allegedly affiliated with [[Delyan Peevski]] and the witnesses against Vasilev.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://frognews.bg/novini/eto-koi-aktivi-ktb-zagrabi-jertvata-peevski.html|title= Ето кои активи на КТБ заграби "жертвата" Пеевски|publisher= frognews.bg| language= Bulgarian|date=22 August 2017|access-date= 1 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://frognews.bg/obshtestvo/underground/biser-lazov-podstaveni-litsa-vzima-102-miliona-ktb.html|title= Бисер Лазов с подставени лица взима още 102 милиона от КТБ|publisher=frognews.bg|language= Bulgarian|date=9 November 2017|access-date= 1 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://frognews.bg/obshtestvo/underground/svideteli-ulichiha-biser-lazov-grandiozni-dalaveri-aktivi-ktb.html|title= Свидетели уличиха Бисер Лазов и Ко в грандиозни далавери с активи на КТБ|publisher=frognews.bg| language= Bulgarian| date=16 January 2017|access-date= 1 December 2017}}</ref>
Vasilev also argues that Bulgarian authorities close their eyes to irregularities in the insolvency proceedings. He was concerned about the fate of Corpbank's strategic assets, such as [[Vivacom]]. In particular, VTB Capital controlled 33% of Vivacom through their daughter company ''Crusher'' even though they were not the true owner as the price of the shares had already been paid by Corpbank's SPV ''Technological Center-Institute for Microelectronics (TC-IME)''.<ref name="Истината за Виваком">{{Cite news|url=https://clubz.bg/30239-istinata_za_vivakom_razkaz_ot_cvetan_vasilev|title= Истината за "Виваком"|publisher=clubz.bg| language= Bulgarian| date=9 November 2015|access-date= 1 December 2017}}</ref> In murky circumstances, the shares of Vivacom were sold by VTB Capital at a devalued rate at a tender in London to Bulgarian Spas Rousev in September 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.capital.bg/biznes/kompanii/2016/09/02/2821528_spas_rusev_v_btk_vremenen_stopanin_5/|title= Спас Русев в БТК: Временен стопанин №5|publisher=capital.bg| language= Bulgarian| date=2 September 2016|access-date= 1 December 2017}}</ref> There is pending litigation before the London High Court for allegedly illegal seizure of the equity stake in Vivacom.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://readrussia.com/2016/03/28/bulgarias-vivacom-shareholder/|title= Bulgaria’s Vivacom Shareholder Sues VTB for Alleged Fraud|publisher=Read Russia| date=28 March 2016|access-date= 1 December 2017}}</ref> Vasilev has raised concern that Vivacom's new owners would probably fail to pay the company's debt to Corpbank and would hurt the interests of the creditors in the insolvency proceedings.<ref name="Истината за Виваком"/> It has been suggested that Spas Rousev is a strawman of Delyan Peevski.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://glasove.com/categories/skandalyt/news/spas-rusev-i-peevski-v-otchayan-opit-da-legitimirat-krazhbata-na-btk|title= Спас Русев и Пеевски в отчаян опит да легитимират кражбата на БТК|publisher=glasove.bg| language= Bulgarian| date=9 January 2017|access-date= 1 December 2017}}</ref>
In the past, Vasilev had tried to strike a deal with a Belgian investor who was supposed to find financing for Vivacom's debt towards Corpbank, but it fell through.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bnt.bg/en/a/lic33-bought-a-stake-in-telecom-operator-vivacom-and-five-other-bulgarian-companies|title=LIC33 BOUGHT A STAKE IN TELECOM OPERATOR VIVACOM AND FIVE OTHER BULGARIAN COMPANIES|last=site.meta-author|website=BNT News|language=en|access-date=2017-10-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegeography.com/products/commsupdate/articles/2015/07/27/lic33-pulls-out-of-vivacom-deal/|title=LIC33 pulls out of Vivacom deal|publisher=TeleGeography|access-date=2017-10-29|language=en-us}}</ref>
== Citizenship ==
Tsvetan Vasilev is ''Doctor Honoris Causa'' of the “St. Ivan Rilski” University of Mining and Geology. He is also recipient of the Honorary Badge of the [[University of National and World Economy]] and a member of the university’s board of trustees.<ref>[http://www.unwe.bg/trustees Board of Trustees page on the official site of the University for National and World Economy] {{en icon}}</ref> He has authored a number of publications analyzing the financial challenges before Bulgaria and the European Union.<ref>[http://www.neurope.eu/article/dual-standards-and-why-they-threaten-europe%E2%80%99s-unity On Dual Standards and Why They Threaten Europe’s Unity, New Europe, 12 December 2010] {{en icon}}</ref><ref>[http://www.neurope.eu/article/bulgaria%E2%80%99s-potential-sustainable-growth-how-enhance-it-2011 Bulgaria’s Potential for Sustainable Growth and How to Enhance it in 2011, New Europe, 1 January 2011] {{en icon}}</ref><ref>[http://www.neurope.eu/kn/article/europe-any-light-end-tunnel Europe: Any Light at the End of the Tunnel?, New Europe, 2 January 2012] {{en icon}}</ref><ref>[http://www.neurope.eu/article/double-ebrd-standards-eu-funding-analysistzvetan-vassilev, Double EBRD Standards on EU Funding, Analysis of Tsvetan Vasilev, New Europe, March 2012] {{en icon}}</ref>
Vasilev is a frequent guest of various international economic forums, such as the Wroclaw Global Forum<ref>[http://www.europost.eu/article?id=4779 Wroclaw Forum Discusses Growth in Eastern Europe, Europost, 8 June 2012, Retrieved 24 September 2013.] {{en icon}}</ref> and the Black Sea Energy and Economic Summit.<ref>[http://www.atlanticcouncil.org/news/event-recaps/energy-and-economic-summit-2012 Istanbul Energy and Economic Summit 2012, Official website of the Atlantic Council]{{en icon}}</ref><ref>[http://www.atlanticcouncil.org/news/event-recaps/black-sea-energy-and-economic-forum-2011 Black Sea Energy and Economic Forum 2011, Official website of the Atlantic Council] {{en icon}}</ref>
Vasilev has sponsored many initiatives in various fields, including scientific research, development of sports, support of orphanages, renovation of churches and monasteries, etc.<ref>[http://www.unwe.bg/bg/news/3252/%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BB%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5-%D0%BD%D0%B0-%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%BE-%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE-%D1%81-%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8-%D0%BE%D1%82-%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BF%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%B0-%D1%82%D1%8A%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0-%D0%B1%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B0.html Top Students Receive Gifts from Corporate Commercial Bank, Newspage on the official website of the University for National and World Economy] {{bg icon}}</ref><ref name="bnews.bg">[http://www.bnews.bg/article-66230 Tsvetan Vasilev Received an Award from the Bulgarian Motorcycle Federation for an Overall Contribution to Bulgarian Motorcycle Sports, bnews.bg, December 23, 2012] {{bg icon}}</ref><ref>[http://novinite.bg/articles/21438/Korporativna-targovska-banka-e-noviyat-sponsor-na-volejbola Corporate Commercial Bank AD is the New Sponsor of Bulgarian Volleyball, novinite.bg, 9 October 2012]{{bg icon}}</ref><ref>[http://www.corpbank.bg/news_470.html Corporate Commercial Bank AD Makes Christmas Wishes Come True Again for Children in Need at the Orphanages in Sofia and Gabrovo, Official website of Corporate Commercial Bank AD, December 12, 2012] {{bg icon}}</ref><ref>[http://bg-patriarshia.bg/news.php?id=15182 Reconstruction of the Sveti Dimitar Solunski Church in the Etara Quarter of Gabrovo, Official website of the Bulgarian Orthodox Church, November 30, 2009] {{bg icon}}</ref><ref>[http://www.politika.bg/article?id=24977 A Monument of Atanas Burov Unveiled, politika.bg, December 9, 2011] {{bg icon}}</ref><ref>[http://www.svetogorie.com/ Official site of the St. Kozma and Damyan Monastery] {{bg icon}}</ref>
He is the main benefactor of [[PFC Botev Plovdiv]], the oldest football club in Bulgaria.<ref>[http://sporta.bg/?load=Football::Article&championshipId=17244&id=1068530 Botev is Ready for the Championship Title, The New Base Proves a Different Model of Development, sporta.bg, 13 september 2013. Retrieved 22 September 2013] {{bg icon}}</ref> Vasilev’s efforts are concentrated on the development of the football club and its junior football academy.<ref>[http://www.gong.bg/view_article.php?article_id=372679 Mury Stoilov Before the Opening of the Base in Komatevo: "This was My Dream", gong.bg, 17 September 2013. Retrieved 22 September 2013.] {{bg icon}}</ref>
== Awards ==
Tsvetan Vasilev has received a number of prestigious awards. He has been the recipient of ''The Banker'' newspaper "Banker of the Year" award for his personal contributions to the Bulgarian economy and banking several times: *Award for Dynamic Banking Management as Chairman of the Management Board of Corporate Commercial Bank AD in 2004<ref>[http://www.corpbank.bg/news_150.html Tsvetan Vasilev Became Banker of the Year, Newspage on the Official Website of Corporate Commercial Bank] {{bg icon}}</ref> *Award for Promoting Bulgarian Capital in Bulgaria’s Banking System in 2008<ref>[http://news.expert.bg/n204438 Banker of the Year Awards, news.expert.bg December 3, 2008. Retrieved 16 September 2013.] {{bg icon}}</ref> *Market Stability Special Award in 2010<ref>[http://money.bg/news/id_1992636838 Banker of the Year Awards, 9 December 2010, money.bg. Retrieved 16 September 2013.] {{bg icon}}</ref> *Award for Efficient Policy and Long-Lasting Presence on the Bulgarian Market in 2013<ref>[http://europost.info/bulgaria/tzvetan-vassilev-named-banker-of-the-year/ Tsvetan Vasilev Named Banker of the Year, europost.info. Retrieved 1 February 2014.]{{bg icon}}</ref> In 2011 he received the Mr. Economy award (the grand award of the ''Economics'' magazine in Bulgaria)<ref>[http://economic.bg/news/169/1/1/MISTUR-IKONOMIKA.html Mr. Economics, Official website of the ''Economics'' magazine] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928163602/http://economic.bg/news/169/1/1/MISTUR-IKONOMIKA.html |date=2013-09-28 }} {{bg icon}}</ref> for overall contribution to the development of the Bulgarian economy.<ref>[http://bnt.bg/bg/news/view/65182/nagradite_mistyr_ikonomika_2011 Mr. Economics Awards 2011, Report by the Bulgarian National Television on 30 November 2011, www.bnt.bg. Retrieved on 4 September 2013.]</ref><ref>[http://www.standartnews.com/mistar_ikonomika_2011/mistar_ikonomika_2011__e_cvetan_vasilev-124919.html Mr. Economics 2011 is Tsvetan Vasilev, ''Standart'' newspaper, November 2011. Retrieved on 4 September 2013.] {{bg icon}}</ref> In 2012 Vasilev received an award for his overall contribution to the development of motorcycle sports in Bulgaria by the Bulgarian Motorcycle Federation.<ref name="bnews.bg"/>
== Personal life ==
Tsvetan Vasilev is married to Professor [[Antoaneta Vassileva]], Dean of the International Economics and Politics Faculty of the [[University of National and World Economy]].

{{Infobox Senator | name = Vincent A. Isidro | image = | imagesize = 100px | smallimage = | caption = | order = | office1 = [[Secretary of Energy (Philippines)|Secretary of Energy]] | president1 = [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]] | term_start1 = 8 June 2001 | term_end1 = 21 March 2005 | predecessor1 = [[Jose Isidro Camacho]] | successor1 = Raphael Perpetuo M. Lotilla | birth_date = May 26, 1958 | birth_place = [[Quezon City]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Filipino people|Filipino]] | party = | spouse = Leigh Talmage (1991-2017) | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = [[University of the Philippines]]
[[Wharton School of Business]] | occupation = Entrepreneur, Environment Advocate | religion = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Vicente (Vincent) S. Pérez Jr.''' (born May 26, 1958) is an environment advocate and renewable energy investor. He is the eldest of five children of Vicente Abad Pérez Sr., a former naval officer and assistant secretary for foreign affairs, and Lucila Siongco Santiago, a dietician and nutritionist by training. His sister Sheila became a missionary, a brother Benedict is a leading Asian equity sales banker in New York, another brother Raoul is an aviation expert, while a third brother Miguel is a fintech entrepreneur. He and his brothers were educated by the Jesuits at [[Xavier School]]. He entered the [[University of the Philippines]] and was active in extra-curricular activities and became national president of [[AIESEC]] Philippines, the national chapter of the international association of business and economics students. Pérez graduated with a degree in Business Economics in 1980."UP School of Economics pays tribute to Perez", Manila Bulletin, June 8, 2005. After his college graduation, he took an AIESEC internship with the international department of New Jersey National Bank in Trenton New Jersey. He then earned his [[MBA]] at the [[Wharton School of Business]] of the University of Pennsylvania"Penn's National Administrators: Men and Women Who Have Served in Notable Positions in Foreign Governments", University Archives and Record Center, University of Pennsylvania, August 2002. in 1983, majoring in international finance. Upon graduation from Wharton, he joined [[The Bank of New York Mellon|Mellon Bank]]'s International Banking Department in Pittsburgh and completed their international credit training program. Pérez was assigned as a Latin American credit analyst and later as Mexico and Central America desk officer. In 1985, he joined Mellon's debt trading team, and was one of the early pioneers in emerging markets debt trading, focusing on Latin American and Philippine debt. While at Mellon, he met a fellow banker, Leigh Talmage, and they married in 1991. Both were involved with emerging debt markets and supported environmental causes. They separated in 2015 and their marriage was dissolved in 2017. In 1986, Pérez then joined Lazard Brothers & Co in London as part of its debt trading team. The following year he moved to [[Lazard| Lazard Frères & Co.]] in New York as a debt trader and investment banker. At 35, he became a general partner of Lazard Frères in 1994 as co-head with Edgar Legaspi of its Emerging Markets Group, becoming one of the highest-ranking Asian bankers on Wall Street, and was named one of the 100 Emerging Markets Superstars by Global Finance magazine.http://www.philstar.com/business-life/134229/vince-perez-energizing-power-sector In 1994, Pérez relocated to Singapore as one of the founding managing directors of [https://www.lazard.com/locations/singapore-fa Lazard Asia]. In 1997, Pérez left Lazard to set up [https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=22087 Next Century Partners], a private equity firm based in Singapore, teaming up with Patrick Go, Dennis Mendiola, John Wallace, and Eduardo Martinez-Miranda. They invested in companies such as [[Smart Communications]], [https://www.delmontepacific.com/ Del Monte Pacific],"Project Pina Colada: Private equity involves high risk and high rewards. Vincent Perez took a risk in the Asia crisis, now he is being rewarded". Forbes Global, September 6, 1999, pp. 80-81. and in semiconductor assembly. Among the co-investors of Next Century Partners were Soros Fund,"Soros Fund invest $45m in the Philippines", Financial Times, March 6, 1998. Mitsui, and one of the Bass Brothers of Fort Worth Texas."Luck is not Enough. Ex-Wall Street exec makes right turns". Philippine Daily Inquirer, November 27, 2000, p. C4. In early 2001, at age 42, Pérez was recruited by his former academic adviser and newly sworn Philippine president [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]] to join her administration. He served briefly as Undersecretary for Industry at the Department of Trade and Industry and as Managing Head of the Board of Investments. He then served from 2001 to 2005 in the [[Cabinet (government)|Cabinet]] of [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]] as [[Department of Energy (Philippines)|Energy Secretary]].{{cite web |url= http://www2.doe.gov.ph/About%20DOE/VSP.htm |title= Secretary Vincent S. Perez |publisher= Department of Energy, Republic of the Philippines |accessdate= 23 November 2013}} As Energy Secretary, Pérez boosted energy self-sufficiency, promoted clean indigenous energy, and crafted an ambitious renewable policy framework. He dealt with solving the frequent grid-wide power black-outs that were hampering the economy then,"Philippines suffers major power cut", BBC News World Edition Tuesday, 21 May 2002. and had to secure the oil supply of the country in the wake of the 2003 Iraq war"If America fights, will Asia suffer?: Vincent Perez is preparing for war, although his nation isn't planning on doing any fighting." Time Asia magazine, January 13, 2003. by pursuing energy diplomacy in Asia and the Middle East."Perez said that the Philippines will have adequate oil stocks in the event an US-Iraq war erupts", Malaya, October 1, 2002. As chair of an ASEAN Energy Ministers meeting, Pérez led the ASEAN Plan of Action for Energy Cooperation for 2004-2009, setting for the first time a regional commitment to attain a minimum 10% of power mix in renewable energy. He hosted the first ministerial meeting of ASEAN plus 3 (China, Japan, and Korea) energy ministers in June 2004."ASEAN energy ministers cite RP's Vincent Perez", The Philippine Star, July 25, 2005, page C2. After overseeing a major restructuring of the Philippine power sector and having initiated the privatization of generation assets of the state-owned National Power Corporation, he resigned in March 2005."Philippine energy official resigns", International Herald Tribune, January 26, 2005. With four years of government service, Pérez was one of the longest-serving members of President Arroyo's economic team, and was cited as the last of her "''touted trio of Wall Street-bred economic managers''"."Perez quits as Energy chief: Exit the last of the Wall Street boys", Philippine Daily Inquirer, January 26, 2005, front page. In announcing his resignation, the Palace issued a statement from President Arroyo citing Pérez’s "''crucial role in implementing difficult power sector reforms, reorganizing the public energy sector, jump-starting the much-awaited privatization of Napocor, and ensuring no more Luzon-wide blackouts since May 2002''". The President underscored the "''valuable contributions made by Secretary Pérez in the country’s quest for energy independence through greater reliance on clean, indigenous and sustainable energy sources''", noting that since 2001, the country has increased its use of indigenous natural gas and geothermal power."Palace statement on the resignation of Energy Secretary Vince Perez", Office of the Press Secretary, Malacanang Palace, January 25, 2005. Since his return to the private sector in 2005, Pérez has been active in renewable power, energy advisory, and conservation issues. He was a 2005 World Fellow"Perez selected Yale World Fellow", Manila Bulletin, August 1, 2005. at Yale University, where he lectured an MBA class on renewable power in emerging countries. Upon his return in 2006, Pérez and former energy officials Jocot de Dios and Lea Ricolcol, founded [http://www.merrittenergy.com/ Merritt Partners], an energy advisory firm. That same year, he was invited by the owners of [http://www.northwind-power.com/ NorthWind], the first wind farm in Southeast Asia, to replace a minority shareholder, and that led him to a decade-long career investing in renewable energy.{{cite web |url=https://www.un.org/ga/president/62/ThematicDebates/bios/perez.pdf |title= Vincent S. Perez |publisher=United Nations General Assembly |accessdate=23 Nov 2013}} In 2008, together with Knud Hedeager, Gerry Magbanua, Poch Ambrosio (all former colleagues from NorthWind), and joined by Antonette de Guzman and Eduardo Martinez-Miranda, Pérez and his partners founded [http://www.alternergy.com/vm.php Alternergy], a renewable power company focused on wind and run-of-the-river hydro, and built the [[Pililla Wind Farm|Pililla Rizal wind farm]] in partnership with Equis Funds. Subsequently, in 2013, he co-founded [http://www.solar-pacific.com/ Solar Pacific], a solar PV developer, with Michael Lichtenfeld, a Yale colleague, and the [https://www.santfoundation.org/ Sant Foundation]. As a private citizen, he was dispatched as Special Presidential Envoy by President Arroyo on economic diplomacy overseas. In 2009, Pérez was appointed as vice chairman of the National Renewable Energy Board."Perez heads renewable energy body", Philippine Daily Inquirer, April 2, 2009. His philanthropy is dedicated to the environment and conservation. Pérez has long been involved with [[World Wide Fund for Nature]] (WWF) starting with arranging debt-for-nature swaps. He was a founding trustee of [https://wwf.org.ph/ WWF-Philippines] in 1996. Pérez was elected to the International Board of WWF, the governing body of the global WWF network,"Former RP DOE Secretary Vince Pérez Appointed to WWF-International Board of Trustees", WWF Philippines Press Release, December 16, 2009. and a member of the boards of [https://en.wwfchina.org/ WWF-China] and [https://www.worldwildlife.org/ WWF-US]. He was active with [http://www.malampayafoundation.org/ Malampaya Foundation], Sikat Solar Car Challenge Foundation, [https://www.solarenergie.ph/ Stiftung Solarenergie Foundation], and in marine conservation through [http://www.asianconserve.com/ACF/Corporate/html/index.html Asian Conservation Foundation]. Pérez has been an independent director of regional companies in Australia, the Philippines, and Singapore. He is an independent director of ST [https://www.sttelemedia.com/about-us/people/ Telemedia], the Temasek holding company for telecom, data centers and mobile technology, and an Independent Board Adviser of Banco de Oro, the Philippines’ largest commercial bank. He is a member of the advisory boards of Bhutan [https://bhutanfound.org/about-us/members/#mr-vince-perez Foundation], Coca-Cola FEMSA Philippines, New Zealand Trade [https://www.nzte.govt.nz/about/our-people/beachheads/southeast-asia-beachhead-advisors/vince-perez Enterprise], Geneva-based Pictet Clean Energy [http://www.philstar.com/business/626482/vince-perez-joins-clean-energy-fund-advisory-board Fund], and the [https://cbey.yale.edu/ Yale Center for Business and Environment] [https://cbey.yale.edu/our-community/vince-perez]. Pérez and his family have had a long affinity with the frontier island of Palawan in western Philippines. He and his brother Miguel set up Stellar Sea Farms to raise red tilapia in sea cages in Culion. They once owned Puerco island in Green Island Bay and currently own Dilumacad or Helicopter island in El Nido. In 2000, he founded Asian Conservation [http://www.asianconserve.com/ACC/html/index.html Company], an innovative venture philanthropy with like-minded conservationists, and together they acquired [http://www.elnidoresorts.com/ El Nido Resorts]. With a management team from Next Century Partners, they transformed it into an award-winning eco-tourism destination in Palawan by pursuing a quadruple bottom line philosophy."The Philippines’ final eco-frontier: A pioneering group of private island resorts is combining luxury with sustainability", Financial Times, August 3, 2013.[https://www.ft.com/content/18f84898-f5ed-11e2-a55d-00144feabdc0] Pérez has written a few publications: “''Chasing Moonlight''” narrated a sailing voyage during his 50th year; “''Chasing Sunsets''”, a compilation of 58 haiku poetry of his travels; and “''Chasing Cherry Blossoms''”, a hiking travelogue with his three brothers in Japan. He co-published “''Voices from the Islands''” featuring how El Nido Resorts became a showcase of sustainable tourism. Pérez is fond of the sea and used to do salt-water fishing and sailing. Together with his sailing buddy Judes Echauz, they won the Rolex China Sea Race on their yacht Subic Centennial, first in 1998 and again in 2008."Hi-Fi and Subic Centennial winners at Rolex China Sea Race", World Sailing, March 25, 2008. Today he remains an avid scuba diver. ==Notes== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Perez, Vincent S.}} [[Category:Filipino bankers]] [[Category:Filipino businesspeople]] [[Category:University of the Philippines alumni]] [[Category:Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1958 births]] [[Category:Secretaries of Energy of the Philippines]] [[Category:Arroyo Administration cabinet members]]

{{Infobox person | name =William Neal Reynolds | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|mf=yes|1863|3|22}} | birth_place = [[Patrick County, Virginia]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|mf=yes|1951|9|10|1863|3|22}} | residence = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Winston-Salem]], [[North Carolina]] | occupation = Chief executive of [[R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company]] | networth = | spouse = Kate Bitting Reynolds | children = (raised brother's children)
Richard Joshua Reynolds Jr. (1906-1964)
Mary Katherine Reynolds (1908-1953)
Nancy Susan Reynolds (1910-1985)
Zachary Smith Reynolds (1911-1932) | alma mater = [[Duke University]] |signature = | footnotes = }} '''William Neal Reynolds''' (March 22, 1863 – September 10, 1951) was a [[United States|U.S.]] sportsman and businessman with [[R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company]], which was founded by his brother [[R. J. Reynolds]]. ==Early life== Born in [[Patrick County, Virginia]], Reynolds went to work for his brother in [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina]] in 1881 as he worked himself through Trinity College (later [[Duke University]]).{{cite web |url=http://www.wfu.edu/history/HST_WFU/reynolds.htm |publisher=[[Wake Forest University]] |year=1994|pages= |title=Dictionary of North Carolina Biography |first=William S. |last=Powell}} From 1890 to 1940, Reynolds served as a director of Reynolds Co. He served as the first vice-president of the company until he took over the presidency in 1918. ==Chief executive of R.J. Reynolds== Always called "Mr. Will,"{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8rVQ6wKWdaYC |publisher=''[[HarperCollins]]'' |year=2003|pages=40 |title=Barbarians at the Gate |first=Bryan |last=Burrough}} Reynolds took over the presidency of the company after his brother's death from [[cancer]] in 1918; he turned the presidency over in 1924 to [[Bowman Gray Sr.]]{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NccTgQkmPIEC&pg=PA593&dq=rj+reynolds+reynolds+temple |publisher=''[[UNC Press]]'' |year=2005|pages=593 |title=North Carolina Architecture |first=Catherine |last=Bishir}} The company then turned from "the dominance of its founder into the less personal sphere of corporate life." Reynolds became the first chairman of the board of directors of Reynolds Co. in 1924 until 1931 and then served as chairman of the board's executive committee until 1941. ==Personal life== Reynolds married Kate G. Bitting in 1889. Reynolds was the first president of the Forsyth Country Club and commissioned a nine-hole [[golf course]] to be built.{{cite web |url=http://www.triadgolf.com/sep98/teetalk.htm |publisher=''Triad Golf'' |date=September 1998|pages= |title=Reynolds and Golf: Longtime Companions |first=Mark |last=Cartner}} After eight years, in 1921, he brought in famed golf course designer [[Donald Ross (golfer)|Donald Ross]] to design an 18-hole course. In 1925, Reynolds founded another golf course, Roaring Gap, about an hour away from Winston-Salem and also designed by Ross. R.J. Reynolds' widow Katharine died in 1924, and their four children were then raised by William Reynolds and his wife, Kate.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oQTmb8DBvIMC |publisher=''John F. Blair, publisher'' |year=1994|pages=183, 194 |title=Winston-Salem: A History |first=Frank |last=Tursi}} Reynolds and Kate had no children of their own. The youngest Reynolds child, [[Zachary Smith Reynolds]], called "Smith," was seven when his mother died. He was [[murder]]ed at the age of 20 at his parents' estate, [[Reynolda House]]. His pregnant wife, [[Libby Holman]], and friend were indicted for the murder, in a sensational case that garnered national attention. Reynolds contacted the district attorney and asked for the charges against his nephew's alleged killers to be dropped; the prosecutor eventually did so for lack of evidence, and no trial on the matter was ever held. The [[Z. Smith Reynolds Foundation]] was established in Smith Reynolds' name by Smith Reynolds' siblings and by Reynolds. The foundation lured [[Wake Forest University]] away from its location {{convert|100|mi|km}} away in [[Wake Forest, North Carolina]] to establish a new campus on the grounds of Reynolda House and receive an annual endowment from the foundation. Reynolds also built a [[hospital]] in Winston-Salem specifically for [[African-American]]s, named the Kate Bitting Reynolds Memorial Hospital in honor of his wife. In honor of his mother, he founded the Cox School in [[Stokes County, North Carolina]] and the Hardin Reynolds School in Patrick County, Virginia to honor his father. The Kate B. Reynolds Trust uses one-fourth of the income collected each year from its more than two million shares of R.J. Reynolds Co. stock to help the "poor and needy" in Winston-Salem. ==Tanglewood== Reynolds built a {{convert|1117|acre|km2|adj=on}} country estate on the [[Yadkin River]] near Winston-Salem, [[Tanglewood Park Arboretum and Rose Garden]], and moved into it in 1921. Reynolds kept [[racehorse]]s at Tanglewood for competition. In the racing season of 1909 to 1910, one of Reynolds' horses won 15 of 17 races conducted. He also owned interests in horse farms in [[Lexington, Kentucky]] and [[Florida]]. He eventually donated Tanglewood to [[Forsyth County, North Carolina|Forsyth County]] for use as a park. Today, Tanglewood has three golf courses; an 18-hole par 3 course, the Reynolds Course, and the Championship Course which hosted the 1974 PGA Championship and was the site of a Champions Tour event from 1987-2002. Tanglewood also has horseback riding, bicycling, swimming and boating.{{cite news |url=http://www1.wfubmc.edu/hematologyandoncology/The+Medical+Center/ |publisher=[[Bowman Gray School of Medicine]] |title=Environment ‑ Winston‑Salem, North Carolina |first= |last=}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Reynolds, William Neal}} [[Category:1863 births]] [[Category:1951 deaths]] [[Category:People from Patrick County, Virginia]] [[Category:American manufacturing businesspeople]] [[Category:American tobacco industry executives]] [[Category:American chief executives]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:Duke University alumni]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Winston-Salem, North Carolina]] [[Category:R.
